Psøma Psi Phi.title: January 11th-March 29th 1983
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
For the first time on a physical format, Psoma Psi Phi offers up a complete collection of the first "season" of thirteen deep ambient Thalo Green recordings. These pieces were originally issued one at a time, the first being released in June 2019, and were published with zero biographical information or provenance. They were made available only as digital downloads at the Thalo Green Bandcamp page (  123524.bandcamp.com  ) and only now have been assembled into a definitive release. Preferring to show and not tell, Thalo Green seems to be a generative process that transfigures television broadcasts into lush ambient sound, and while we were able to make contact with the mind(s) behind Thalo Green (and its sister project, Thalo Blue) and officially license this edition, we have been asked to respect the agency of the artist and refrain from any further discussion about who they are, where they're from and why they've made these recordings.
Musically, the Thalo Green recordings resemble a number of things that reside within the deep listening spectrum - sustained tone drone music, vague clouds of orchestral fog that bring to mind Wolfgang Voigt's Ruckverzauberung works and extremely focused minimalism that echoes meditative classics by Eliane Radigue, Pinkcourtesyphone or Harry Bertoia. These sounds are both able to dodge direct observation and command the removal of other distractions, and for this, we feel they are incredibly versatile in purpose, from sleep sound, to reading or bathing music, to meditative/yogic prompts and even as an atmospheric backdrop for creative work such as writing or painting. They are a direct contrast from the Thalo Blue recordings, which are not only more modest in their runtimes, but more aquatic and filled with subtle movements, whereas the Thalo Green recordings feel Earthen and forestial. These relationships could simply be the need of the human mind to arrange things and interpret them based on a minimum of external stimuli, in this case, a single shade of the color green, but one would not be faulted in thinking that these colors may have been chosen for their synaesthetic qualities just as much as their aesthetics. It is our sincere hope that Psoma's re-publishing of these recordings will bring them to a wider audience that we feel will truly benefit from their effects, both long and short term, and this hope is equaled by another, that the mind(s) behind Thalo Green and Thalo Blue will continue to record new music in the future.
NOTE: Due to the considerable amount of audio contained in this release, Psoma Psi Phi has elected to issue the material on two DVD-R discs, which contain the original unaltered 16-bit 44100Hz WAV format audio files that were sent to us. We feel that this keeps the ritual of a physical edition intact and available, while also reducing unnecessary shipping bulk and material costs. All standard DVD players and computers should be able to play these discs, although for more practical/portable listening, users are encouraged to generate their own lossy file conversions.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released March 5, 2021
W/P by Thalo Green. Text and physical package design by ABM&D for Psoma Psi Phi. Digital release design courtesy of Thalo Green. This is Psoma Psi Phi number TGS1.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: KVK
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Psøma Psi Phi introduces a new artist on Ø20 - Anna Generator - and her debut recording KVK. Live and entirely improvised using only a Korg analog polysynth, a Boss RV-3 delay unit and a Peavey mixing desk, KVK is a surreal landscape of playful synthesis that recalls early electronic music such as Wendy Carlos, Tzvi Avni, Alvin Lucier and others. Produced with a minimum of sequencing and a focus on pulling sinews of sound apart, accumulating them into gigantic whorls of sculpted mass. While experimental and untamed, it clocks in at a modest runtime of about 14 minutes, so Psøma has augmented this release with an extended reappraisal of KVK by label head Brian Grainger that explores the liminal spaces between KVK's steep collisions to a deep and hypnotic effect.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released February 23, 2020
W/P by Anna Generator, except #3, Written by Anna Generator / Produced & remixed by Brian Grainger. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Psøma Psi Phi number ØΨΦXX.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: LA
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
It's been over a year since Psoma issued new work in David Burraston's open-ended NYZ subcatalog - a point we're looking to rectify with a crop of no less than three new releases.
The second of this new triad is LA, another statement of generative intent. A sonic exploration made with his trusty MANIAC sequencer and a heavily modified Roland MT-32. NYZ’s interest in Roland’s Linear Arithmetic synthesis technology dates back to the Roland D-10 in 1988, his third ever synth. We spoke to NYZ about this obsession :
“I wandered into Carlsbro Sound Centre [music shop at the top of Mansfield Road in Nottingham, UK] one day in 1988 and as luck would have it they were selling an ex-demo one at about half price. So I leveraged my Juno 106 in part exchange and got it for even less. Top deal.
No regrets, it’s an ocean more interesting than the 106 for what I was doing. Besides, I still had my Jupiter 4 and Korg MS20 for analogue stuff, so it was a bit superfluous anyway. My ultra-tiny bedroom studio at the time needed a wider sound palette. The D-10 is not a great synf, but I like it. I had a real love-hate relationship with it for several years. Mainly gripes around certain programming limitations and the UI which is a bit painful.
A key draw for me, apart from the PCM ROM samples, are the ‘structures’ as Roland calls them. Some of them are additive, but a bunch of them are also Ring Modulator [RM] based. My RM obsession was already in full swing. I’d previously built a Practical Electronics / Phonosonics Ring Modulator, designed and sold by the legendary John Becker. This was was a key item in my studio, so the D-10 would fit in nicely.
I got rid of the D-10 sometime in the 90’s. But those old digital Roland’s really do have a lovely sound, if you spend the time programming them up a bit. They really are best via a computer editor. I have a couple of D-110’s [which have the world's worst manual, and a UI to match], three MT-32’s and a D-5. The D-5 is only very slightly different, but actually better imho. The MT-32 is similar again, but has a fairly different set of ROM samples in it + two of mine have the ultra rare Robin Whittle mod. I don’t have a D-50, but I got the D-05, which is their boutique remake that got discontinued just after they made it :( come on Roland, hit us up with another from the LA stable one day, plz! :) ”
As for the music on this album, you can rest assured this is some classic NYZ gear and then some. LA sonically connects with and departs from his other outings such as RLD GLD and NTE GDN. Here we see NYZ really focusing his auditory microscope. LA represents the start of yet another intense series of synthetic investigations. We open up with a couple of short fun algorithmic ditties, NYZ even breaks out the whistle PCM sound here! After this opening cleanser, he’s off into classic realms of cellular exploration in his own inimitable style. Morphing his own identity as he travels. The album’s entire second half is from three experimental sessions where his generative music systems explore something we can’t find words to properly describe. You’re on your own from this point on - we travelled out there. with no idea what planet we ended up on, but what a trip it was.
So watch out for more in the LA series at some unspecified time in the future!
---

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Location
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Location is a composite recording, assembled via two sparse and barely processed room recordings from both of my previous studios (Rolling Knoll and Botany Bay), bound together with a noise generator and a sleep-deprived, lazy handed improvisation on the Korg MS-20 analog synthesizer. Channeled live across just over two hours through an Alesis Quadraverb patched into the vintage circuits of a JVC KD-A11 cassette deck and rendered down to a very low volume via the ample EQ curves of my Peavey FX2x24 mixing board. The result is a discrete atmosphere of occasional movement in a vast pool of white noise and vaguely tonal suggestion - spaces transmuted into sound, transfigured for spaces.
NOTE: Like Ameliorator before it, Location is mastered at a quiet level, and it is recommended for playback on speakers/systems with a wide dynamic range, and headphones, preferably with noise cancelling capabilities.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released October 22, 2017
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, Autumn 2017, using binaural room recordings of Rolling Knoll and Botany Bay in Columbia, SC, Summer 2016 in conjunction with Korg MS-20 analog synthesizer, Grass C-TCM, Alesis Quadraverb, JVC KD-A11 cassette deck and Peavey FX2x24 board. Mastered by The Analog Botanist.This is Psøma Psi Phi number ØΨΦIII.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: LXXIII
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Following his two-hour sections of the massive ØΨΦII split, Arjen Schat returns to Psøma Psi Phi with a proper solo release named LXXIII. This recording came about partially after I urged Arjen to expand on an improvisation he did on his Rhodes electric piano (which was released as a part of the charity compilation 3067 Megs:  meganmccarthy.bandcamp.com/track/rhodes-improvisation  ), and he delivered beautifully, as he always does.
To my ears, LXXIII recalls so many of my favorite aspects of Arjen's music and other ambient milestones. The drifting overtone drones immediately conjure up things like Primal (a personal favorite of mine), while the sound of the Rhodes invokes the crystalline stillness of Eno & Budd's Plateaux Of Mirror. Further still, certain melodic sections of LXXIII feel weathered and isolated, sad even, in a similar fashion as Aphex Twin's essential work on SAW II (namely a track like "Lichen"). In short, there is a lot to love about this release, for fans of many different eras of classic and modern ambient music.
Arjen always displays such a masterful hand with his instruments, and an impressive level of restraint in both the performance and the production of a piece like this. Long may he continue to sculpt entire universes from the simple clay of vibrations floating through air.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released June 14, 2018
W/P by Arjen Schat. Recorded at Infraklang, 2017. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Psøma Psi Phi number ØΨΦV.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: M
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
OCR is the second nom-de-guerre for Brian Grainger and John-Paul Kramer's collaborative work - the first being Occur, which has (thus far) released two EPs and one LP at Recycled Plastics. Existing in tandem with Occur releases will be the OCR catalog here at Psoma Psi Phi - a parallel universe reimagining of the band's work, presented as extended beatless pieces instead of their more rhythmic electronic counterparts.
This first release, simply titled M, consists of two lengthy de/reconstructions of Occur's debut EP, Drum. If Drum could be the sound of the not-too-distant past in the history of electronic music, M is the incredibly far-flung future, where life as we know it has been wiped from the Earth, and all of civilization breaks down into so much dust and empty space. M solemnly hangs in the sour air, like a burned flag sagging off of a bent ruin. Gone are the signs of life or even nature herself, with only traces of regret and sadness running through the abandoned remains. A quiet night sets over the scene, looked down upon by meaningless stars in an indifferent sky. No more warmth, fire or blood. Just this.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released February 18, 2018
W/P by Brian Grainger & John-Paul Kramer. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, February 2018 using only source from Occur's Drum EP. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design & texts by ABM&D. This is Psoma Psi Phi number OCCUR 1, first in the ongoing OCCUR subcatalog of works.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Meditations
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Mosca returns to Psoma, following the brutalistic High Rise - an album of dystopian synthesis inspired by JG Ballard's novel of the same name - and the transcendent Sacred Space double-album - a collaborative work with a visual artist that recalls the stark minimalism of pioneers like Eliane Radigue and Alvin Lucier - with the aptly and simply named Meditations, consisting of four hour-long sessions of drone that shimmer and hum in the most sonorous ways.
Each Meditation is specifically designed to liberate the listener from a type of mental and emotional dissonance - fear, anger, pain and desire, respectively - and certainly, when listening, it is apparent that Mosca's timbres and their different frequencies overlap in harmonious relationships, bringing a sense of calm stillness to the body, and hopefully relaying these sensations to the brain, where the real work must be done.
And yet, these recordings must also acknowledge the futility of such an effort - the biological fact that we cannot simply re-wire ourselves to divorce our minds from our bodies, much as we may feel compelled to, given the world and time we find ourselves living through - but still they persist in their denial of that world, a tangible line of disconnection drawn between our inner selves and our outer suffering.
For us, these sessions are more than simply music, they are a tool to be employed, not if but when the world becomes too much for us to bear. They cannot themselves alleviate or erase the fear and anger we feel, or the pain inflicted upon our bodies, and they cannot supplant or satiate our desires, no matter how modest they may sometimes be, but they can soften the blows of these things. They can provide a very real and useful mechanism with which to process grief and suffering, and in turn, if this recontextualizing of pain allows one of us more opportunities to push more positivity into the world, then perhaps in this sense, the Meditations do quantitatively improve the state of things.
Of course, what feels harmonically sound and relaxing to us may be incongruous dissonance to someone else with different eardrums, different cranial dimensions or curvatures - indeed, such small details from person to person can affect oceans of differences in how the brain and body respond to simple sustained frequencies - but the intent remains immutable. There is no right or wrong way to accomplish what Mosca has set out to do here - the revelation is in the doing, in the grasping of that power we possess as humans, to design and manifest systems that help us become more of ourselves, and less of the imprinted surroundings that are inevitably cast upon all of us. Should we wish for more, for better, we can accomplish it, starting with ourselves.
NOTE: This digital release is an abridged version of the complete album, and only includes the first of four discs of material. Listeners who would like to hear the full album are encouraged to purchase the physical edition to do so.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Metal Cell Meditations
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
David Burraston returns to Psoma Psi Phi with his seventh release for the label, and fifth bearing the Noyzelab moniker. Metal Cell Meditations is the fourth of a five-part series that will be issued serially between October 2018 and February 2019.
The recordings presented here are, as the title implies, intended to assist in meditation, and operate as minimalistic walls of humming drones, parsed out into pre-determined "dosages", to assist in their usage as a utility. Only have three minutes before you have to go to work? There's a 3-minute Cell Meditation for you here. Need a harmonic backdrop for your yoga session or your power nap? Cell Meditations also come in 5, 10, 15, 20 and 30-minute sections. For those of you seeking a deeper experience, Burraston has also provided 45 and 60-minute versions of these Meditations, perfect for disconnection, introspection and all manner of subconscious stimulation. As is his usual, Burraston's work treats time itself as an elastic band that passes by at a rate of his choosing, and for this we've come to be quite addicted to these recordings, even finding ourselves lost inside a three-minute drone. In this fashion, Noyzelab has essentially created an infinite generative structure, and these segments are in fact windows of varying lengths of time, through which we're able to observe and experience something that is impossibly large and unfathomably deep. Be careful with these Meditations - even the artist himself has issued a text advisory in the notes for these recordings - for they are potent and finely distilled examples of the current the universe itself moves through, from element to element.
NOTE: The digital version of NYZ-VII contains only the 20-minute Meditation. For the full and unabridged Metal Cell Meditations experience, listeners may purchase the limited edition 3xCD-R set.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Metal Edict
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Metal Edict is one such 'sleep fiction' as mentioned in the label's statement of intent, and a deep listening experience for both headphones and room playback. Built using a single source recording of a piezoelectric microphone attached to an industrial appliance, which then became layered and processed via a number of studio machines and effects units, Metal Edict hovers like a fog on a distant and desolate planet. Red sand dunes as high as mountains, like frozen waves, ripple across a surrealistic landscape, and somewhere inside the cloudy haze above them we can make out a single inorganic structure - a dark plinth, a solitary watcher standing what could be miles into the sky. This much is all there is to observe and contemplate, the rest has been left unsaid by the artist's subconscious, leaving Metal Edict to provide a liminal space between here and there. Meaningful or meaningless? Substantial or vacant? Purposeful or random? There are no words etched on this Metal Edict to provide an answer.
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released March 29, 2019
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, March 2019, using a piezoelectric microphone in tandem with pitch processors, analog/digital reverberation and delays and a number of resonant low-pass filters and parametric equalizers. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Psøma Psi Phi number ØΨΦX.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: MM2
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
For his twenty-fifth release in the ongoing NYZ catalog, David Burraston arrives with MM2, a nearly seventy-minute exploration of the GForce Minimonsta2. The Minimonsta2 itself is a software replication of Moog's well-known Model D subtractive analog monosynth, albeit with some modern additions, such as a reverb effect and the ability to modulate the pulsewidth of oscillator 1.
In the past, Dave's had little opportunity through the years to play around on a Minimoog - stray sessions here and there - and until now, he's been unable to find the 'sweet spot' on the machine for his particular requirements. Thanks to the generosity of Jerome Meunier at GForce, Dave was sent a copy of the Minimonsta2 software, finally allowing him a deep dive on the instrument, and the resultant recording is as transcendent as any of the Cell Meditations sessions or other 'DRN' iterations before it.
The MM2 session consisted of a special drone-focused arrangement utilizing four different instances of the Minimonsta2, each individually processed through a separate Serum FX strip. Each layer was spaced an octave apart, allowing for some ultra-subtle detuning and drift via the circuit modelling, as well as the FX.
This recording is a companion to other GForce synth sessions of ODT3 and SEM on Psoma, and the earlier OSC2 release on Superpang, continuing the software studies on those releases, while also conveying gorgeous pillars of drone music in the way that only NYZ methodologies can. The vibrations present on MM2 are like ripples in space-time, overlaid in psychedelic modulations with one another, expansive and incredibly dense all at once. MM2 is, like most NYZ recordings, highly recommended for headphone listening as well as higher-decibel playback on speaker systems with sufficient low frequency output.
---

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Moments Scattered Like Sand
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Blaubac, one of the few artists able to migrate between Psoma and her sister imprint Recycled Plastics, offers up Moments Scattered Like Sand as his debut within the Ps Ps Ph catalog. Though beatless, Moments could be considered a followup to Blaubac's RP entry (see: BC68 / A Dim Vision) - both have been created and carefully refined via a modular synthesis arrangement, and where A Dim Vision cast us into the fallout of a deleted-technology heavy world, Moments exiles us even further out into the wastes, past the borderlands, beyond the last vestiges of post-humankind and the afterbirths of civilization. Perhaps this reflection on/of bleakness is too intense for some, given the world's current outbreak-infested state, but for us here at Psoma, it is perfectly apt and well-timed. Something dark to cast your anger and frustration into, a pit of black quicksand to renew your sense of hope and purpose through this immutable vibrational ritual.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: MTP4
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
It's been over a year since Psoma issued new work in David Burraston's open-ended NYZ subcatalog - a point we're looking to rectify with a crop of no less than three new releases.
The first of this new triad is MTP4, the newest iteration in NYZ’s ongoing exploration with GForce software synthesis instruments. A real beauty, made using the M-Tron Pro IV, where we get to witness a spaced out long-form drone exploration in intricate slow motion. Apparently, NYZ has been witness to a real Mellotron in Bradbury’s studio too. Regarding the Mellotron he notes :
“It’s a really amazing early tape based sample instrument, and the software version is incredible! It’s definitely out there on its own. Coming from the UK I also heard it back when it came out in the 60’s as a little kid. It left a lasting indelible impression on my mind. So the opportunity to have a great software version is really something else. When Jerome got in touch and asked if I was interested to have a copy I immediately said yes please! I was delighted and very grateful for their support. Awesome crew. Thanks folks! Once it was installed I disappeared for a few days, and this is one of the drone sessions I worked on. Utterly blissful I thought. I didn’t want to leave the studio, I thought I was in some crazy kiddy dream :)”
We happily invite you along with NYZ on another GForce synth session in the spirit of MM2, ODT3 and SEM on Psoma, and the earlier OSC2 release on Superpang. As an expanding series of releases, NYZ bathes us yet again in a gorgeous oceanic herbal bath of drone using his own pioneering methods and techniques. We have been enjoying it here of a late evening, but this is a “totally anytime/anywhere you need it” piece of work.
---

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Multisignal Amplification Studies For The SSM-1750
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Cut from the same deep sessions that yielded Bacchus Tapes 6 (Poseideon:  cordtapes.bandcamp.com/album/poseideon  ) and the two Multiplicative pieces presented on the Psoma 29 split with NYZ, these three longform recordings are detailed and hypnotic studies of feedback in motion: sampled, looped, overlaid in multiple pitches equally tuned apart from one another, until a swirling sea of incomprehensible frequency-bending wash surrounds the listener, filling up eardrums, rooms, whole universes, before being pulled down the drain of a black-hole low pass filter. A no-input configuration using an SSM-1750 mixing board (built and sold by Radio Shack in 1995) was the sole sound source utilized to create these intense landscapes.
Inspired by recordings from the noisier and quieter end of the beatless music and synthesis spectrum (Vainio, Chartier, Aube, Lopez, Omit, Acre), Psoma 30 can be used as a mental cleansing device, a utility of equalization and balancing, recalibrating and resetting your input receivers to better function after you've been completely clogged up by the information age. Additionally, it can also take the form of a negating fortress, an impenetrable wall that drowns out the difficult and unpleasant outside world that many of us wish to remove ourselves from at various times.
100% of the proceeds from sales of Psoma 30 (as well as Psoma 29) will be sent to the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. Fuck racism, fascism, sexism, homophobia, bigotry, discrimination and hatred in all forms.  www.naacpldf.org

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Murmur To The Night
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Murmur To The Night arrives as Psoma 38, bearing a nearly 3 hour digital component and a more modest 70 minute CD-R edition. Being one of my first sessions to come from building a modular synthesizer system, this recording was significant for being the first time my yet-to-be-named R-EW Audioholistics system would be able to convey more subtle and restrained audio, rather than the usual "severe" and angular material it was capable of in the very beginning. Murmur feels influenced by a number of classic synthesizer recordings, from Radigue's Adnos to Eno's Neroli, with notable nods to Teibel's Tintinnabulation as well, while being wholly apart from all of these things. It feels dimly lit and cautious, perhaps filled with the sense that the ground could drop out from beneath you at any moment in the undefined darkness. It also feels sloth-like and languorous, content to remain close to motionless for extended periods. Recorded during the Springtime of 2020, when the pandemic was just beginning to get a death-grip, Murmur kept me company during many restless nights, when I needed something to distract me from the outside world, and focus again on a quiet and dark room.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: MYZTRYZ
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
MYZTRYZ is a tripartite assemblage of unpublished material, hailing from as far back as eleven years ago, in the Noyzelab studio. An overflowing cornucopia of pointillistic and synthesized delights, no maps or detailed notes are provided to aid the listener, offering a freefall into chaotic and overstimulating sound-worlds that could be compared to the sensation one gets listening to Coltrane's 'Ascension' for the first time. Chaos has always been close to the core of Burraston's work, both in his studies and his music, exploring and organizing microcosms of possibility, through methods both arcane and academic, and on MYZTRYZ this focus dominates. Still, for all of the complexity and surrealism present in these collage-like constructs, NYZ feels as playful as ever, with moments of hesitant uncertainty in the shadows abruptly giving way to splashing in oily puddles with childlike abandon - both approached with mathematical clarity. MYZTRYZ, for several reasons, could be considered Burraston's 'Out to Lunch' as much as it could also be a 'Greatest Hits' retrospective in some parallel universe. Everything presented here feels unique, formidable in one way or another, but still familiar, owing to Burraston's inimitable way with the machines and their systems. This is expansive, surrounding music that confounds as much as it compels - as Iggy Pop once wisely said: "What sounds to you like a big load of trashy old noise is in fact the brilliant music of a genius."

Psøma Psi Phi.title: O-E U
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
"O-E U" is a branching path from Milieu's "Enantiomorphosis III" and was recorded during the same session, with the same patch and equipment, albeit with a different scale in the sequencer and a different post-processing approach. As an LSZ composition, it is the mid-point between "Sill" and the forthcoming "Aius Loquens" in its exploration of resonators and unorthodox sequencing.
"O-E U" consists of the Behringer 1047 module, a re-creation of the resonator present in the ARP 2500 system, which acts as a pingable filter with notch, low-pass, high-pass and band-pass output signals, and it is also able to track pitch reasonably well, for a self-oscillating filter. This machine was sequenced in the Trivalent scale in Zeus temperament 7, with the Ornament & Crime multipurpose module, taking timing information from a constantly changing trigger array that consists of Boolean gates and two different sub-dividers - one even-numbered (Doepfer A-160), and one probabilistic (Cute Labs' Missed Opportunities). A Turing machine system was utilized to decide the values for rests/sustains, note choices and octaval differences in the sequencer, and the final resultant audio was given a wider stereo profile using Strymon's Magneto four-head tape delay system. From here, the recording was overlaid onto itself in two subsequent pitch iterations - one an octave up, sent through a different panned stereo delay, and the other an octave down, sent through a feed-forward reverb system using a Householder matrix in Airwindows, which was itself multed and played with an offset between the stereo channels.
"O-E U" is what I'd consider both functional as comforting ambient listening, as well as engaging at the compositional level when the listener chooses to focus on it, once again reiterating for the umpteenth time what Eno defined all those years ago. I find it fascinating to have published different albums under different project headings connected at a deep level, almost as if they can consider each other as parallel universe counterparts. Neither one is the true work, both are reflections in an imperfect mirror that descends into a deeper green the further you look.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Octalz
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
For his tenth release at Psoma Psi Phi, David Burraston brings us a new hour of Noyzelab recordings bearing the title Octalz. Two sets of three related tracks (KW1octalR and RLDoctalMPP, respectively) that shift slowly between foggy, static atmospheres and looping passages of chords that seem outright melodic compared to Burraston's usual fare in our catalog. Rest assured, Octalz remains alien and distant, defying conventional description or traditional genre trappings, instead bathing the listener in sheets of textures that seem both thin and warm at the same time. Quick and dirty comparisons might mention names like Mika Vainio's Ø recordings or even Oval's 94 Diskont, but deeper and repeated listening will reveal Burraston's inimitable sonic fingerprint, which seems more and more like that of an engineer on some archaic starship - built in our near-future but kept afloat centuries later, filled with green screens and bulky disk drives and overheating analog circuitries. Burraston is endlessly tinkering, considering, refitting and revising the things that serve other musicians as instruments, but to him, are simply tools. His recordings suggest a universal harmony that can be found in feedback paths, algorithmic processing and pure random noise, perhaps the outline of some mathematically definable but otherwise unfathomable shape in the silent chaos of stellar bodies and celestial objects. Octalz is the latest transmission from this surveyor of the frontier, bringing the void (and all of its great and terrible possibilities) closer to us.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: ODT3
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Continuing from SEM with his exploration of GForce software instruments, Burraston builds a wall with the Oddity3, an expansive modern iteration of the ARP Odyssey that includes several new additions and functions. ODT3 consists of two such instances of the Oddity3 to accomplish the wide stereo image, both focusing on the 4035 ladder filter from the short-lived Odyssey mark II (only one of three filter types present within the softsynth). Landing somewhere on the map between the Cell Meditations and the subharmonic hums of TESCO SYNFETIX, ODT3 pulses in shallow waves that betray the depth beneath their softened surfaces. Close listening yields wondrous results, especially in headphones, as the swirling mass of the frequency spectrum slowly rises like a shipwreck called back to shore. Almost imperceptibly, the true substance of this piece is revealed in microscopic increments, until it overtakes the senses and surrounds everything, filling the air with vibrating particulate and soporific electricity, glimmering like a portal to an adjacent dimension.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Pale Blue
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Originally broadcast for International Sloth Day in an online A/V stream on October 20th, 2022, 'Pale Blue' is a generative ambient recording that was composed in realtime by the R-EW Audioholistics modular system. It consists of a patch centered around Mutable Instruments' Rings, a digital Karplus-Strong synthesizer, being sequenced in the Dorian scale by two Ornament & Crime modules with timing information coming from a Turing machine.
This broadcast followed Milieu's 'Creation' - a twelve-hour overnight session - that quietly started a series of longform generative ambient works issued twice a month, following an online stream of the patch, however 'Pale Blue' was much more modest in length, at only two hours, and so it was decided that it would be better suited to a release here at Psoma.
'Pale Blue' is being offered as a low-priced digital release and physically as a limited edition 2xCD-R set. It can now be seen as a figurative branch between Milieu's work in the Psoma catalog and the ongoing longform broadcasts happening outside of it, and would appeal to any listeners that enjoy generative sound, slow-motion synthesis and indistinct yet accessible audio that may be used as a utility for reading and writing, sleeping and meditating, painting and programming.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Pass
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
It started sometime during the night, as the first buildings fell. Without warning, the black was lit up in orange as dozens of small charges were dropped from invisible metal wings. The distant bombs woke you as you dreamt of a shore you've never visited, and the sound was so thick that you could not be certain how far away it really was. You sat up, and looked outside, unable to see much through the growing smoke clouds that filled the neighborhood like a grey fog. Living beneath the overpass, you'd become accustomed to the sounds of vehicles and people moving through the air around you, but the vibrations emanating from deeper in the city were alien compared to that.
A faint tone began to emerge from between the impacts - perhaps planes, or sirens, or both? - it was impossible to tell what was happening. Without a second hesitation, you packed your knapsack with the essentials, and grabbed a small battery-operated radio on your way outside. The car was a lost cause, useless in this smoke cover, and who knew what state the roads were in. No, this was a departure you needed to make on foot.
You turned your gaze toward the fence at the end of your street, the opposite direction from the city, and swiftly jumped it to land unsteadily on the dirt, still wet under the dew of the evening. Picking up a stride, with your back to civilization, you passed by the old water tower, and jumped a ditch that carved out the last line of demarcation between your subdivision and the deeper, untamed woods. Like Lot walking away from Sodom and Gomorrah, you understood that things may never be the same - how could they be? Or, perhaps more importantly, why should they be? Answerless questions, filler for a mind that was still trying to grapple with the idea that the human race could finally be finished.
You weren't sure what you expected to find, or where you expected to go, trespassing through the dark woods like this, but it was forward movement, and that was all you needed to feel okay. Hours passed, along with the very occasional pylon standing guard in long hallway-like cutaways leading back to the power grid - back to the death. Stopping at one such location, you startled under the sudden lights and drones of a plane zooming by overhead. You instinctively jumped back into the dark brush, feeling that whoever might be on that plane might not be looking for survivors. As the sound of the craft faded from earshot, trails of overtones came and went on the barely-there wind that blew through the trees. You were approaching an opening of some sort, a clearing or even a body of water, and the breeze pointed you toward it.
Emerging from the forest, you stood silently at the precipice of a man-made lake. You'd never seen this before, and certainly it wasn't on any maps. An almost imperceptible hum wavered up from beneath the stone walls that held the still water. As your ears followed it, your eyes met with muted lights in a circular formation, far below the wet surface. In your hand, you tightened your grasp a little around the small radio, which began to crackle to life with strange sounds. Something was coming into range, on the AM band, and your fingers carefully nudged the dial toward it.
"You've found us" crawled out of the small radio speaker, the voice a whisper between the bands. The circle of lights began a slow advance to the surface.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Peint Arbre
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Initially recorded between Summer and Autumn of 2009, then stashed away in the shade for almost nine years, my collaborative full-length album with Peter Wright is now finally issued forth into the universe. A mammoth album of drones, feedback, sub-bass harmonics and psychedelic textures, set across three different pieces, Peint Arbre is a dense and enveloping trip through the tangential and exploratory minds of two men, working almost 8,000 miles apart.
Peter Wright, if you are unaware, is an outright legend of drone music, guitar improvisation and spectacularly filmic textures, having been active in the New Zealand experimental music culture since 1992. I've long been influenced by his recordings, and in 2009 I was lucky enough to host his epic Snow Blind double-album at INSTALL, the now-defunct label I co-operated with David Tagg. We followed Snow Blind with a vinyl release of Wright's transcendent Orbit, and he also guested on my One Bleak Try album, lending many additional layers of sonic seasoning to the track "Black Rust Caress."
Since INSTALL closed its doors years ago, I've wanted to give this unreleased album we did a proper release. Since so much time had passed, Peter decided to revisit the recordings and add/subtract some things to bring it into its present form (so for those few out there who heard this album in its previous iteration, this is a different beast). Peint Arbre is an interesting cross-pollination of my distorted bass monolith drones, generated using guitar and organ in the Rolling Knoll studio, and Peter's contributions of guitars, vocals, percussion and all sorts of other instruments. Indeed, it feels very alive, and that is almost all Peter's doing - I merely provided the initiative steps. So it follows that hopefully another collaboration is due between us, and the door is of course always open for Peter to issue something of his own here at Psøma Psi Phi.

released December 3, 2018

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Phase Accumulator
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Polysilicon is perhaps better known as Chris Moore, a producer who has been issuing varying shades of electronic music under the name While since the mid-nineties, starting with a track on Skam's MASK 400, and continuing onward via Chocolate Industries, Musik Aus Strom and even our beloved friends at Earstroke (see: Ourson's 'Collected Natures I-III'). His first album under the Polysilicon name is Phase Accumulator, and it exists in a very different part of the electronic music landscape than While recordings previously occupied.
Recorded entirely live using only a Yamaha TX216 and an Eventide H949, Phase Accumulator is a tableaux of droning timbres and machine minimalism that conjures blurry visions of color, temperature and light, which feel impossibly synthetic and starkly elemental, sometimes simultaneously. This kind of material should feel alluring and familiar to our long-time listeners, who are more than familiar with the glassy tones of FM carriers and operators, and the unorthodox shapes that this type of improvisational exploration often yields.
The thirty-six minutes offered here seem to convey a far deeper well, elongating the runtime by way of manipulated perception, and many of the pieces could continue to oscillate forever. Surrealistic, at times chaotic, but always fascinating and expressive in ways that even these words fail to describe, Phase Accumulator is a trip best taken with headphones or on a surround system with adequate low-frequency output, and an unexpected companion to the slow thawing of the Winter season.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Phytolith
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Limestone Ziggurat returns with "Phytolith," an extremely minimal wall of sound, topically reminiscent of certain Eliane Radigue recordings. "Phytolith" was created using three barely processed sinewaves from the Grass Click-Tone Control Module - a piece of racked hospital testing equipment that was not developed with music-making in mind. Originally, all three sinewaves were designed to be played separately via different output systems on endless tape loops, but this method of presentation was abandoned and the assemblage offered here is what remains of the session.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: PLL
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
After much preparation and discussion, the first volume of a new and ongoing series from David Burraston has arrived at Psoma: PLL, a catalog of recordings made using Phase Locked Loops.
For this first excursion Dave is using the Doepfer A-196 Phase Locked Loop module. The PLL is, even by Doepfer's own admission, an unusual and unpredictable device, which is remarkable considering the wild frontier of ideas that populate the modular music world. It continues to either astound or confound music makers who are new to its specific strengths and unorthodox charms. In layman's terms, the PLL uses a voltage controlled oscillator, a phase comparator and a low-pass filter in a combinatorial way, alongside two external input signals to track various aspects and adjust them internally according to a set methodology. The result is often an untamed and colorful source of processed audio and/or angular modulation, although, like many Doepfer modules, the PLL can act as an external sound processor or a sound generator itself.
This is where Burraston arrives to both discern what is happening inside the PLL, and to shape and guide it according to his own conceptual bent. We here at Psoma cannot say we fully understand what Burraston is doing on these recordings, even though we ourselves use the PLL in our own modular system, but that liminal space between recognition and unfamiliarity is often where NYZ recordings reside - threading a cosmically large tapestry with electricity, while most listeners experiencing this process from the outside will not be able to distinguish the advanced experimentalism from pure, mind-melting magic.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: PMFM
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Dave Burraston's newest entry in his expansive NYZ catalog is PMFM, a mind-melting exploration of FM synthesis as only he could facilitate it. Using the unimaginably deep EssenceFM synthesizer, which boasts a behemoth 300-voice polyphony, PMFM weaves into and out of spaces that feel fully elemental. Humming overtone-rich drones shiver and break apart as spasms of textural electricities disintegrate their surroundings. Strange resonance pervades a constantly shifting stereo field that brings to mind visions of parallel timelines overlapping in thin wavering halos. PMFM is as much a monumental accomplishment in the world of FM synthesis as it is a sonic black hole that pulses ever-present on the bleak horizon. A welcome disconnection from this reality, or any other.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: PPLZ SYNF
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
David Burraston returns to Psøma Psi Phi with possibly his most expansive release to date - PPLZ SYNF. A gigantic 3.5 hour work consisting of seven pieces created using an ongoing self-build (as Burraston notes) of the Serge/CGS Paperface analog synthesizer, in conjunction with a custom built modular rig. Laid to digital disk space at Burraston's Noyzelab studio in August, PPLZ SYNF is a monolith of drone synthesis that absorbs the listener into some kind of greater collective metaconsciousness. It is both an impressive exercise in longform drone music, and an immersive and hypnotic atmosphere that confounds the mind, transfiguring your surroundings from its unique and singular perspective. A monument, literally and figuratively, in the sound field, etched and erected by a master of the craft.
Given the scope and size of such a release, PPLZ SYNF has been committed to a very special, and very limited, triple-cassette set, housed in a dustproof binder. These are extremely finite and assembled by hand in every possible way, making no two copies exactly alike. The digital version available at Bandcamp consists of cuts from the first of the three tapes, while the full release is spread across two 60-minute tapes and one 90-minute tape.
UPDATE 2018.03.04: The 4xCD-R reissue is now stocked at Norman Records in the UK  www.normanrecords.com/records/169774-nyz-pplz-synf
NOTE: After some confusion from listeners, we'd like to make clear the fact that all NYZ/Noyzelab catalog releases at Psoma are available ONLY as abridged digital versions for name-your-price/free download, and in their full unabridged editions as physical CD-Rs. There is not an unabridged digital version of anything from NYZ at Psoma, and the physical editions do not ship with unabridged digital versions either (that is, if you do not count the digital music present on the compact discs). For listeners only interested in unabridged digital versions, we encourage you to visit  noyzelab.bandcamp.com  to purchase those directly from NYZ, or even better, subscribe to his Bandcamp output and just get everything.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Psalm
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Duenn is a self-described experimental composer from Fukuoka, Japan, who worked with me previously on the collaborative recording "Presence", issued at Opal Tapes in the UK. He approached Psoma some time ago, and through some correspondence we arrived at this beautiful quiet album called Psalm. Seven tracks of evocative minimalism, one of which also features a collaboration with Takuro Okada (who previously released work with Duenn at Chihei Hatakeyama's White Paddy Mountain imprint three years ago). These pieces are warm and inviting, and easily imply scenes of stillness and contemplation in slow environments. Duenn's music works well for the intimate moments of introspection we all have, gazing out a window or waiting for sleep to claim us in our beds, and arrives right on time for a pleasant Autumn season here in the midwestern United States.
Duenn and I have also completed a second collaborative recording, Absence, which will be released before the end of this year. Contented listeners are encouraged to explore Duenn's catalog of work, issued at such excellent places as LINE, Entr'acte, and/OAR and Past Inside The Present, as well as via Duenn's own self-released outlets.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Resonant Forms
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Resonant Forms is the first three-way split release issued in the Psoma catalog, consisting of three different blocks (around 20 minutes each) of improvised music, contributed by three different guitarists: Adrien75, Brian Grainger (myself) and Rik Johnson.
Having been friends with and influenced by Adrien75 for several years, it was surprising to both of us to stumble over the fact that we were also both mutual admirers of Rik Johnson's beautiful work with the instrument. It felt predetermined then, that we should all at least attempt some kind of collaborative release, and once Rik agreed to join us for it, I set up the basic rules: We would each submit around 20 minutes of material, which could be a single piece or many different ones, using only live takes of improvised guitar music. There were no restrictions on processing or FX devices, only that there should be no overdubbing and everything played should be as informal and unprepared as possible. In short, I wanted to hear the sound of the three of us playing guitar, and nothing else.
Stylistically, what emerged is a beautiful set of performances that all seem to sense each other, despite each of us working separately without hearing what the other two were doing. All three of us used subtle detuning effects, filters and reverbs, making the set somewhat unified despite hundreds of miles and radically differing rigs between us.
Opening the set is Adrien75's single piece, "A Series Of Ordeals", which is a suite of several movements in and out of looper sprawl and textured fray, that immediately recalls his lush guitar work on the landmark album Coastal Acces, issued in 2002 on Source Records.
From there, Rik plays five different pieces of melancholic chord changes, gorgeously evoked from finger picked sections and overlaid lead lines that weave around in forward and reverse motions. Rik's work is the least well-known of the three of us, something Adrien and I feel is a criminal shame. It reminds me of lots of different things that I love about quiet and sad guitar music...Roy Montgomery, Manual, Loren Connors, even a little Mogwai. Hopefully, Psoma 16 puts Rik's work in more people's ears, where it clearly belongs.
Closing the release is my contribution, "Seconds", a single extended piece I played using a handful of different pieces of processing FX that I'd inherited or bought from another close friend, guitarist and influence, David Tagg. "Seconds" is filled with looping mountains of ambient blues, similar to some of my past albums like Eight Thousander, Nine Billion Names and Blue Wheatfield.
After completing the work for these pieces, we all three agreed that we'd like to attempt further iterations of this idea, in the future. For now, Resonant Forms stands as a very accessible and, we think, potent entry in the Psoma catalog, and an engaging sixty-minute tableaux of improvised guitar music that pairs well with the Autumn season.
ADRIEN75 :  adrien75.bandcamp.com
RIK JOHNSON :  inanycasethemoon.bandcamp.com
BRIAN GRAINGER :  briangrainger.bandcamp.com

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Sacred Space (Two Paintings)
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Following his excellent analog synth exploration of J.G. Ballard's "High Rise", Mosca returns with a collaborative double-album named Sacred Space, consisting of two extended sessions of luscious drifting synthesis that effectively "score" two original paintings by artist/designer Michelle Haswell hanging on his studio wall.
The first of two, "Black (Sacred Space)," unfurls a wide cloak of dusky chords across a full hour's runtime, alternating between subtler sections of closed-filter light trails and fuller, reverberant passages that offer a dimly lit view of an overcast landscape in the evening, on the precipice of a great storm. The second piece, "Grey (A Passing Place)," provides a dense and foggy counterpoint to the deep breathing swells of "Black," with a thick haze of cloudy resonance that feels as if it could be made of evaporated sections of "Black" after the storm has passed.
Both pieces convey a beautifully mesmerizing atmosphere of darkness, where night is not a frightening time or place, but simply a respite from the brightness of the day. Listening to Sacred Space, one might find it hard to pinpoint where exactly the tonal and melodic shifts come to pass, that so effectively keep the recordings in motion and not quite definable as drone music, while maintaining the mystifying sense that these shapes are organic and elemental and alive, but almost imperceptibly slow.
Mosca will return for a third time later this year with Meditations, a massive quadruple-album set of intimate drones designed for various modes of disconnect.
NOTE: The digital edition of Psoma 35 contains extended mixes of both pieces, while the 2xCD-R edition contains special CD-only edits.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Season One
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
For the first time on a physical format, Psoma Psi Phi offers up a complete collection of the first "season" of thirteen deep ambient Thalo Blue recordings. These pieces were originally issued one at a time, the first being released in March 2019, and were published with zero biographical information or provenance. They were made available only as digital downloads at the Thalo Blue Bandcamp page (  000f89.bandcamp.com  ) and only now have been assembled into a definitive release. Preferring to show and not tell, Thalo Blue seems to be a generative process that transfigures television broadcasts into lush ambient sound, and while we were able to make contact with the mind(s) behind Thalo Blue (and its sister project, Thalo Green) and officially license this edition, we have been asked to respect the agency of the artist and refrain from any further discussion about who they are, where they're from and why they've made these recordings.
Musically, the Thalo Blue recordings sound oceanic, with swells of watery chords soaked in dark reverberation, ebbing in and out of gentle washes of white noise. They bring to mind some of Eno's early work such as On Land, albeit much more elongated and abstract, in the way that they seem to paint scenes and locations with a minimum of information. The sounds shift through many different sections of varying color depth, sometimes sounding like organs, other times resembling gusts of wind, with some moments even implying things like human voices, whale songs or orchestral instrumentation.
They are a direct contrast from the Thalo Green recordings, which are far longer in runtime, and more monochromatic in their range, and the most distinct difference is that while Thalo Green's pieces are titled only with dates, Thalo Blue's pieces all bear very vivid names, all of which seem to evoke the natural world, the elements and even specific locations such as Mount McKinley in Alaska - notable for being the highest mountain peak in all of North America.
It is our sincere hope that Psoma's re-publishing of these recordings will bring them to a wider audience that we feel will truly benefit from their effects, both long and short term, and this hope is equaled by another, that the mind(s) behind Thalo Green and Thalo Blue will continue to record new music in the future.
NOTE: Due to the considerable amount of audio contained in this release, Psoma Psi Phi has elected to issue the material on two DVD-R discs, which contain the original unaltered 16-bit 44100Hz WAV format audio files that were sent to us. We feel that this keeps the ritual of a physical edition intact and available, while also reducing unnecessary shipping bulk and material costs. All standard DVD players and computers should be able to play these discs, although for more practical/portable listening, users are encouraged to generate their own lossy file conversions.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: SEM
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
SEM is a long form drone made using a single instance of the GForce SEM - a faithful recreation of the 1974 Oberheim monophonic analog synthesizer, reinstated on the occasion of Tom Oberheim's birthday. Not completely familiar with the machine prior to this session, but previously having played with other Oberheim designs such as the Matrix 6R and XPander, Burraston opted to simply explore it without any additional machines or effects processors, in order to allow the SEM to illustrate its personality naturally, which resulted in the gorgeous pillar of tone that sits before you now. Thematically, SEM relates to prior NYZ recordings such as OSC2 at Superpang and the independently released BS2::DRN4, although avid listeners will appreciate the uniqueness of SEM even when aligned with earlier work. SEM was made possible with the generous assistance of Jerome Meunier at GForce & AFX, and is offered as the twenty-first recording issued in the NYZ subcatalog at Psoma, continuing a rich lineage of vivid synthesizer music and unmapped experimentation.
NOTE: After some confusion from listeners, we'd like to make clear the fact that all NYZ/Noyzelab catalog releases at Psoma are available ONLY as abridged digital versions for name-your-price/free download, and in their full unabridged editions as physical CD-Rs. There is not an unabridged digital version of anything from NYZ at Psoma, and the physical editions do not ship with unabridged digital versions either (that is, if you do not count the digital music present on the compact discs). For listeners only interested in unabridged digital versions, we encourage you to visit  noyzelab.bandcamp.com  to purchase those directly from NYZ, or even better, subscribe to his Bandcamp output and just get everything.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Sencha
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Dominic Razlaff, hailing from Braunschweig, Germany, is the guiding hand behind the prolific DR moniker that has issued music with labels such as Lagerstätte, Tandem Tapes, Shimmering Moods, Histamine Tapes (and literally dozens more). He has offered a careful and considered ambient piece called Sencha to Psøma Psi Phi, a welcome addition to the growing catalog. Soft, quiet and understated, Sencha almost sounds as if it is the shadow of something else that is never completely revealed. Implied shape, deferred movements, distant vibrations all coalesce into a singular focused breath, exhaling across 56 minutes. On a more personal level, Sencha arrived at a time of loss, and very much helped to soothe when soothing was necessary. We hope that it will continue to be a balm to those in need of a calm and comforting space, and we warmly welcome Dominic to the P / Psi / P estate.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Shapes Perceived In Blackness / Colors Perceived In Silence
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Having worked together on many different occasions in the past, Arjen Schat and I have once again collaborated for this massive P / Psi / P release.
Essentially a four-part album of two original pieces and two reinterpretations, Shapes Perceived In Blackness consists first of "Mantra", a nearly hour-long piece from Arjen's studio of a few years ago now. It would not feel out of place next to works like Primal or Oppidium Arnoldi Villa, both records I've spent literal years inside, exploring. Arjen's work was paramount for my mental health when my daughter Penelope was born and came home from the hospital. When I could only take small breaks for rest, Arjen's music was constant at my bedside, effectively deflating the stress from my mind and body and letting me get the most out of the downtime I had.
Backing Arjen's stellar piece is an equally long atmosphere titled "Obviation", which was also recorded years ago now, and for one reason or another, left to quietly age in a box in the studio. Intended as a tape-worn, humid companion piece to Arjen's crystalline monolith, "Obviation" recalls the sticky Summer nights so frequently present in my old studio in the subtropics. Hovering, almost-chords waft between slow gusts of air, analog fuzz and hiss-crusted phaser waves.
I was recently honored with the invitation to pen the liner notes inside Arjen's forthcoming vinyl LP Spectrum (check it out here:  arjenschat.nl/album/spectrum  ) but I feel it is pertinent to note that this release should also serve as evidence for just how much love and respect I hold for Arjen's work. That we can continue forward with our ideas in any kind of unison is a pleasure and a career highlight for me.
NOTE: The physical version of this release comes with two more extended pieces, each of us reinterpreting and recontextualizing each other's piece, making it a four-disc affair. The additional 2-disc release is titled Colors Perceived In Silence, and is exclusive to the physical format.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Sonnenschein
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: Following his Psoma debut Sencha, Dominic Razlaff returns with a sun-kissed set of four ambient pastorales, aptly named Sonnenschein. Round warm tones and fuzzy field recordings coalesce to provide a perfect companion to the melting Winter ice as the cold recedes and allows a bright green Spring to flourish. Texturally and chordally similar to other Psoma releases such as Milieu's Wind Over Hill and Saito Koji's Winter Journal, Sonnenschein is a blanket of drifty sound matter for you to curl up inside, filled with the wordless and surrealistic comforts of a waking dream.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Spring Equinox
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Recorded on the vernal equinox, the beginning of Spring in the Northern hemisphere, this aptly named piece offers a ray of sunlight to warm yourselves beside in the Winter. The band, Picture Rather Muted, consists of Psoma alumni Nicholas Maloney (also known as Blanket Swimming) and Victoria Maloney, who collaborate in sonic as well as photographic terms.
To our ears, 'Spring Equinox' is like a blanket to surround yourself with, full of humming timbres that have been assembled with careful and patient hands. It would appeal to fans of sustained tone minimalism (such as the previous catalog contributions from Limestone Ziggurat, Mosca, Leigh Coleman, NYZ and of course Maloney himself) and will yield much richer listening experiences with either a nice set of headphones, or an open-air speaker system with considerable bass frequency output.
Listeners interested in more from PRM can visit:  picturerathermuted.bandcamp.com

Psøma Psi Phi.title: SRi RLD
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
SRi RLD could be David Burraston's most accessible release at Psoma to date. It presents ever-shifting movements between melodic bell-like tones and more breathy sustained passages of metallic pipe pitches, and the four pieces offered occupy a unique position for a NYZ album, which allow them to be experienced in an abstract wash of sound, as you might normally approach NYZ recordings, or they can be focused on in different moments, forming melodious shapes and suggestions of harmony and resolution. In this way, SRi RLD is perhaps more in the vein of classic ambient music by Eno, Carlos, Rabe and Lucier - compositions that could be appreciated to the same degree that they could be ignored, by design. As ever, Burraston continues to offer the widest array of synthesized sound from his studies, a continually tantalizing journey for the rest of us to eavesdrop on as it comes to pass.
NOTE: After some confusion from listeners, we'd like to make clear the fact that all NYZ/Noyzelab catalog releases at Psoma are available ONLY as abridged digital versions for name-your-price/free download, and in their full unabridged editions as physical CD-Rs. Psøma Psi Phi.title: Summer Evaporated
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
Unexpectedly, much like the previous catalog entry Wind Over Hill, Summer Evaporated emerged as a tangential exploration of an outtake from the recently completed sessions for an album called Daughter. It felt appropriate to append this release to Psoma 6 as an extension, as it once again addresses the changing of seasons - something that has far more weight and dynamism living here in an Ohio valley, than it did (or didn't) in the Carolinian subtropics. Evaporated is a more (more?) minimalistic exercise than Wind, echoing the lethargy at the end of warm months, a resignation to the cool air, burnt leaves and fading greenery.
Into the welcoming arms of Autumn, bountiful cornucopia of orange hue and cinnamon smoke, melted down around the sun-cast apples of Summer. Open a window, lie down with an old paperback and listen to the sound of the sunshine dissolving into perfumes of dust and hiss, fertilizing the Earth as it sleeps beneath the soil...
Psøma Psi Phi.credits:
released November 2, 2018
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, September 2018, using frequency modulation softsynths processed via Moog ring modulator/step filter/low pass filter, Pioneer spring reverb, Alesis Quadraverb, BBE Two Timer analog delay and a Boss RV-3 digital reverb. Laid to Scotch non-virgin reel to reel tape on a Roberts 450A tape machine, with final digitization and EQ processing via a Peavey FX2 24-channel mixing board. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Psøma Psi Phi number ØΨΦVI.II. Text and design by ABM&D.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: Sustain (Low Frequency Version)
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about: An alternative mix of "Sustain", which originally appeared alongside David Burraston's field recordings of Bethungra Dam on a split release (Psoma 18), offered as a longer and deeper experience, yielding totally different harmonic responses and glacial, resonant tones now brought to the forefront of audio playback systems with a wide range of output and ample sub-bass response. Inspired in equal parts by Earth, Folke Rabe and Aube, Sustain explores the relationships of resonant metal-coil springs through careful sampling and processing via an array of modern and not-so-modern sampler systems, including a Boss RC-20 & RV-3, Alesis Quadraverb, Korg ES-1 & Volca Sample and an Akai S2800, with final mastering and editing taking place in a software environment using filtering and reverberation tools developed by Arturia, Image Line and Goldwave.

Psøma Psi Phi.title: TESCO SYNFETIX
Psøma Psi Phi.label: Milieu Music Digital
Psøma Psi Phi.about:
While an otherwise unaware observer might think that issuing five triple-album sets of Noyzelab drones, in five months, might be too much, those in-the-know will understand that there is no such thing as "maximum" when it comes to David Burraston's drones. They are endless macrocosms of sound, a sonic drug of transmuted galactic bodies and alchemical distillation. They ARE.
So, it is with great pleasure that Psøma Psi Phi is able to offer the first NYZ release in the catalog since the 4xCD DSP TRX: a three-track 90-minute excursion bearing the title TESCO SYNFETIX.
TESCO, at first listen, may seem to hover in the air with a static disposition, but upon deeper listening (and especially at higher volumes) it becomes quite clear that this is not a stasis of any kind, but a LONG and SLOW vessel moving glacially through fluorescent space. The occasional buzz and rattle of a machine in an adjacent room occurs, a subtle reminder of this synthesized passage through some unmapped void. The high frequency whine of what could be thousands of hydraulic veins pries open the stereo field to blinding widths, and the soft detuned midrange fog of CRT monitors and ground hum massage the eardrums beneath it. Further back, further down and further out are sublime sub-bass structures, the warm engine core of whatever this gargantuan ship really is.
The whole physical experience of TESCO SYNFETIX brings to mind what it might sound like to travel inside something, that is inside a larger something, that is moving behind and between dimensions at unfathomable speeds, folding spacetime to reach otherwise impossible destinations. A psychedelic and illuminating listen, no matter what your mind's eye casts out for the duration, and an engrossing addition to Burraston's masterful catalog of synthesizer music at Psøma Psi Phi.
NOTE: The limited edition 90-minute cassette contains the complete and unabridged TESCO SYNFETIX album, with three tracks. The digital version consists of only the second track.
NOTE: After some confusion from listeners, we'd like to make clear the fact that all NYZ/Noyzelab catalog releases at Psoma are available ONLY as abridged digital versions for name-your-price/free download, and in their full unabridged editions as physical CD-Rs. There is not an unabridged digital version of anything from NYZ at Psoma, and the physical editions do not ship with unabridged digital versions either (that is, if you do not count the digital music present on the compact discs). For listeners only interested in unabridged digital versions, we encourage you to visit  noyzelab.bandcamp.com  to purchase those directly from NYZ, or even better, subscribe to his Bandcamp output and just get everything.
